title: The British isles through an opera glass,
author: Taylor, Charles M.
snippet: They walk up, and coast down these hilly highways. The Glen is about a mile and a half long, and runs along the foot of the Downs Mountain. Its sides, which rise to a height of six hundred feet, are densely covered with copsewood.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: The drive along the river Dargle is beautiful. The Glenof the Downs is a lovely dell walled in by mountains. We had aview of Glendalough, or, as it is often called, the Seven Churches, whereone of the finest round towers in Ireland may be seen.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: In ancient times it was the abode of theColquhouns. Glen Fruin, or " The Glen of Sorrow," was thescene of the celebrated conflict between the Macgregorsand the Colquhouns, in 1603. The country surroundingthe lower part of Loch Lomond has been the theatre ofmany a sanguinary contest between rival clans.
